paper.title: Development and deployment of a supply-chain digital tool to predict fluid-milk spoilage due to psychrotolerant sporeformers
paper.abstract: Psychrotolerant sporeformers pose a challenge to maintaining fluid milk quality. Dynamic temperature changes along the supply chain can favor the germination and growth of these bacteria and lead to fluid milk spoilage. In this study, we aim to expand on our previous work on predicting milk spoilage due to psychrotolerant sporeformers. The key model innovations include (1) the ability to account for changing temperatures along the supply chain, and (2) a deployed user-friendly interface to allow easy access to the model. Using the frequencies and concentrations of 8  Bacillales  subtypes specific to fluid milk collected in New York, the model simulated sporeformer growth in half-gallons of high-temperature, short-time (HTST) pasteurized fluid milk transported from processing facility to retail store and then to consumer. The Monte Carlo simulations predicted that 44.3% of half-gallons of milk were spoiled (defined as having a bacterial concentration >20,000 cfu/mL, a conservative estimate that represents the Pasteurized Milk Ordinance regulatory limit) after 21 d of refrigerated storage at consumer's home. Model validations showed that the model was the most accurate in predicting the mean sporeformer concentration at low temperatures (i.e., at 3�C and 4�C; compared with higher temperatures at 6�C and 10�C) within the first 21 d of consumer storage, with a root mean square error of 0.29 and 0.34 log 10  cfu/mL, respectively. Global sensitivity analyses indicated that home storage temperature, facility-to-retail transportation temperature, and initial spore concentration were the 3 most influential factors for predicting milk spoilage on d 21 of shelf life. What-if scenarios indicated that microfiltration was predicted to be the most effective strategy to reduce spoilage. The implementation of this strategy (assumed to reduce initial spore concentration by 2.2 log 10  cfu/mL) was predicted to reduce the percentage of spoiled milk by 17.0 percentage points on d 21 of storage and could delay the date by which 50% of half-gallons of milk were spoiled, from d 25 to 35. Overall, the model is readily deployed as a digital tool for assessing fluid milk spoilage along the supply chain and evaluating the effectiveness of intervention strategies, including those that target storage temperatures at different supply chain stages.
paper.summary: This paper develops a predictive, supply-chain–wide model for growth of psychrotolerant sporeformers in HTST pasteurized fluid milk under dynamically changing temperatures. The model represents bacterial population dynamics with a piecewise primary growth model (lag, exponential, and stationary phases) and explicitly accounts for temperature-driven adjustments of lag duration and maximum growth rate using secondary models based on cardinal temperature relationships and Zwietering-type lag adjustment rules. The model is embedded in a Monte Carlo framework to simulate half-gallon containers along the chain from processing facility to consumer homes, predicting spoilage probability (exceeding 20,000 cfu/mL) and evaluating intervention strategies such as microfiltration and improved refrigeration at different chain stages.

target_quantity.name: sporeformer concentration
target_quantity.description: Population level of psychrotolerant sporeforming bacteria in fluid milk during lag phase

parameters.name: initial spore concentration
parameters.source: Table 1; Initial spore concentration at facility follows a normal distribution (mean -0.723, standard deviation 0.990, minimum 0, maximum 0.308)

equations.applicability: Lag-phase segment of the primary growth model for psychrotolerant Bacillus spp. sporeformers in HTST pasteurized fluid milk along the cold chain. Applies for times t less than or equal to the current lag duration under a given temperature history.
equations.text_context: Lag phase (t 4 lag): N = N0. Used as the first segment of a piecewise primary growth model describing psychrotolerant sporeformer growth in milk.
equations.explanation: This equation specifies that during the lag phase, the bacterial concentration remains at the initial level N0. It forms the first part of a piecewise growth model used to track psychrotolerant sporeformers in milk, which is critical for predicting when spoilage thresholds will be exceeded under various storage scenarios.
equations.notes: Assumes no net growth during lag; N is typically represented on a log10 cfu/mL scale in the model implementation.

equations.latex: N = N_0 + \mu\,(t - lag)\quad\text{for } lag < t < t_{max}

target_quantity.name: sporeformer concentration
target_quantity.description: Population level of psychrotolerant sporeforming bacteria in fluid milk during exponential growth phase

parameters.name: initial spore concentration
parameters.source: Table 1; Initial spore concentration at facility follows a normal distribution (mean -0.723, standard deviation 0.990, minimum 0, maximum 0.308)

parameters.name: time to reach maximum population (start of stationary phase)

equations.applicability: Exponential growth phase of psychrotolerant sporeformers in refrigerated HTST milk, between the end of lag and the start of stationary phase, under temperatures where growth occurs.
equations.text_context: Exponential growth phase (lag < t < tmax): N = N0 + �b5(t 2 lag). Forms the linear (in log scale) segment of the primary growth model used in the fluid milk spoilage simulations.
equations.explanation: This equation describes exponential growth of the bacterial population on a log10 scale, with slope equal to the maximum growth rate µ. It is central to predicting how quickly sporeformers approach the regulatory spoilage threshold under given time–temperature profiles.
equations.notes: Assumes constant effective growth rate µ between lag and tmax; N is modeled additively on a log10 scale, equivalent to exponential growth on a linear scale.

target_quantity.name: sporeformer concentration
target_quantity.description: Population level of psychrotolerant sporeforming bacteria in fluid milk during stationary phase

parameters.name: time at which Nmax is reached

equations.applicability: Stationary phase of psychrotolerant sporeformer growth in fluid milk, after the population has reached its maximal density under given environmental conditions.
equations.text_context: Stationary phase (t 5 tmax): N = Nmax. Represents the plateau in the growth curve once carrying capacity is reached.
equations.explanation: This equation caps bacterial growth at a maximum level, representing stationary phase. It ensures that simulated populations do not increase indefinitely and influences the predicted timing and extent of fluid milk spoilage.
equations.notes: Nmax values are implied from underlying data or literature and may vary with strain and temperature; explicit Nmax values are not listed in the provided excerpt.

equations.section: MATERIALS AND METHODS > Model Development > Model Parameters

target_quantity.name: temperature-adjusted lag duration
target_quantity.description: Lag phase duration adjusted from an old reference temperature to a new storage temperature

parameters.name: lag duration at the previous temperature

equations.applicability: Used whenever milk moves between supply-chain stages with different temperatures (facility, transport, retail, home) to update the lag duration of psychrotolerant sporeformers according to Zwietering-type temperature scaling.
equations.text_context: Equation 1 is cited in Table 1 for computing new lag parameters (lagF, lagT, lagS, lagT2, lagH) from base lag and observed temperatures, following Zwietering et al. (1994).
equations.explanation: This secondary model rescales the lag time as a quadratic function of the ratio of effective temperatures relative to a baseline T0. It allows the model to dynamically adjust bacterial lag duration when temperature changes, which is essential for realistic spoilage predictions across variable cold-chain conditions.
equations.notes: Exact value of T0 is not provided in the excerpt; lagadj is used as an intermediate quantity for further lag updates.

equations.section: MATERIALS AND METHODS > Model Development > Model Parameters

target_quantity.name: elapsed lag fraction
target_quantity.description: Cumulative fraction of lag phase already consumed under a sequence of temperature conditions

variables.name: duration of exposure in segment i

parameters.name: lag duration corresponding to segment i temperature

equations.applicability: Used to track how much of the lag phase has effectively elapsed when milk experiences a series of temperature steps, following Zwietering's lag accumulation approach.
equations.text_context: Equation 2 defines lagelap as the sum over segments of exposure time divided by segment-specific lag, enabling partial lag completion to be carried over between temperature changes.
equations.explanation: This equation computes a dimensionless measure of how far bacteria have progressed through lag, accounting for varying lag durations at different temperatures. It is pivotal for correctly propagating prior temperature history effects on subsequent growth.
equations.notes: Implementation uses S time intervals whose lag_i values are derived from Equation 1 or other lag–temperature relationships.

equations.section: MATERIALS AND METHODS > Model Development > Model Parameters

target_quantity.name: updated lag duration after elapsed lag evaluation
target_quantity.description: Remaining lag time after considering accumulated lag fraction under previous temperature history

equations.applicability: Applied after computing lagelap when the accumulated fraction of lag is at least 1, indicating lag is fully exhausted and cells are ready to grow exponentially at the new temperature.
equations.text_context: For lagelap 5 1, lagnew = 0. This rule ensures that once cumulative lag has been consumed, no additional lag is imposed at the new temperature step.
equations.explanation: This conditional update rule terminates lag once the accumulated lag fraction reaches unity or higher, switching the growth model from lag to exponential behavior. It prevents overestimating the lag phase when milk has already experienced substantial pre-growth exposure.
equations.notes: Pairs with the complementary rule for 0 4 lagelap < 1 defined in the adjacent equation.

equations.section: MATERIALS AND METHODS > Model Development > Model Parameters

target_quantity.name: updated lag duration with partial lag completion
target_quantity.description: Remaining lag time at the new temperature when cumulative lag is between 0 and 1

parameters.name: lag duration adjusted for the new temperature

equations.applicability: Used when cumulative lag fraction is between 0 and 1 to compute the remaining lag duration at the new temperature, allowing partial carry-over of lag completion.
equations.text_context: For 0 4 lagelap < 1, lagnew = (1 2 lagelap) �d7 lagadj. This equation scales the adjusted lag by the unconsumed fraction of lag.
equations.explanation: This rule calculates how much lag remains after considering partial completion under previous conditions, then adjusts that remainder to the new temperature. It ensures a smooth transition between temperature steps in the dynamic spoilage model.
equations.notes: Together with Equations 1–3, this defines the lag carry-over mechanism adapted from Zwietering et al. (1994).

equations.section: MATERIALS AND METHODS > Model Development > Model Parameters

target_quantity.name: new maximum growth rate
target_quantity.description: Maximum specific growth rate at the new temperature when the temperature change is small

parameters.name: maximum growth rate at the previous temperature

equations.applicability: Applied when the absolute change in temperature is less than 25% of the previous temperature; in this case, the growth rate is assumed unchanged between the two conditions.
equations.text_context: For |Tnew �13 Told| < 25% Told: �b5new = �b5old. This is referenced in Table 1 for updating �b5T, �b5S, �b5T2, and �b5H under small temperature changes.
equations.explanation: This equation implements a threshold rule whereby modest temperature changes are considered insufficient to alter the maximum growth rate. It simplifies the dynamic growth model and avoids excessive recalculation of µ for minor fluctuations.
equations.notes: Complemented by a separate rule for larger temperature shifts (Equation formula20).

equations.section: MATERIALS AND METHODS > Model Development > Model Parameters

target_quantity.name: temperature-adjusted maximum growth rate
target_quantity.description: Maximum specific growth rate at the new temperature after a sufficiently large temperature change

parameters.name: maximum growth rate at the previous temperature

equations.applicability: Used when the absolute temperature change is at least 25% of the previous temperature, scaling the growth rate quadratically with the effective temperature ratio, similar to the lag adjustment model.
equations.text_context: For |Tnew Told| �1c5 25% Told: �b5new = ((Tnew �13 T0)/(Told �13 T0))2 �d7 �b5old. This rule updates growth rates for substantial shifts in storage temperature across supply-chain stages.
equations.explanation: This equation provides a secondary model that adjusts the maximum growth rate when temperature changes are large. By using a quadratic function of effective temperature above a baseline T0, it captures the non-linear sensitivity of sporeformer growth to refrigeration temperature and is crucial for realistic spoilage risk estimation.
equations.notes: Specific T0 value is not given in the excerpt; the structure mirrors the lag adjustment formula in Equation 1.
